Poor UX from reuse of O hotkey in the Image menu
Poor UX from reuse of O hotkey in the Image menu

note.body:
Actually, depending on what you used last, the mneumonic is different. If you used Image Properties last time, then the next time it'll only take ALT-I O to get Crop to Content. But if you used Crop to Content last time, it takes ALT-I O O. This makes it impossible to have any sort of muscle memory, especially since when you're still learning the mneumonic, you're likely to make mistakes and accidentally select the wrong one. I imagine the problem only worsens when you have more than two clashes.

Having a slightly longer mneumonic is fine, but it needs to be the same no matter what sequence of actions happened previously.

events.target_title: Mouse cursor stuttering on 3.34.1 Wayland

note.body:
I went a day without extensions, and the issue persists.

Weirdly, I have narrowed down one instance when the mouse starts stuttering, as it is not always present. Whenever there is some sort of animation in Firefox (e.g. the tab animation when loading a site, page scroll animation) the issue appears and the mouse is stuttery until the animation stops (i.e. the tab finishes loading, the scrolling stops and the page view is static).

Edit: Playing videos in Firefox also exhibits the same behavior.

events.target_title: Mouse cursor stuttering on 3.34.1 Wayland

note.body: I just tried installing and running Firefox X11, and the issue seems to have disappeared. Makes sense since Fedora 31 switched to Firefox on Wayland by default.

note.body:

Edit: I have noticed that VS Code also causes the bug, whenever an editor is open and the cursor is blinking (my setting was "phase") the cursor is stuttery, even when the editor is in the background. Disabling the blinking animation or closing the editor makes the stuttering stop.

*  Reduced Memory Usage
*  Less CPU usage and omnipresent tracker-extract processes
*  Less slowdowns after creating lots of files (extracting the content of an iso for example)

I am not sure reducing the size down to 10000 is a fit all solution (although i am yet to experience issues with it), but reducing it down from it's current default is, in my opinion, definitely a good idea.

events.target_title: meson: Order glib-2.0.pc Libs entry correctly to fix static builds
Meson Build Failure on Windows: Undefined Reference to libiconv

note.body:
This isn't about glib's direct use of libiconv and !759 doesn't help. libintl depends on libiconv regardless. Unfortunately it doesn't install a pkg-config `.pc` file, only a Libtool archive `.la` file, which Meson ignores. This is only an issue when building statically. I encountered the issue while trying to build QEMU but as seen above, it also happens when building the glib tests.

I'm not sure what the right answer is. I suspect we may struggle to get GNU gettext to install a `.pc` file for libintl. We could just check for libiconv regardless when libintl is needed but that will result in overlinking in the dynamic case if `-Wl,--as-needed` isn't used. I checked the Meson docs to see if it had something that could help here but I came up blank.

events.target_title: meson: Order glib-2.0.pc Libs entry correctly to fix static builds

mutter-3.34.0 will not compile without wayland
mutter-3.34 crashes with gnome on X11
mutter-3.34 crashes with gnome on X11

note.body:
A further datum point.  If I compile mutter-3.34.0 with optimization switched off (namely, with the --buildtype=debug option) then it seems to work correctly when starting under X11.  This suggests that there is some undefined behavior in mutter's implementation which gcc is optimizing against.  gnome seems generally to ignore C's strict aliasing rules and I wonder if that is the problem - is -fno-strict-aliasing applied?

I am using gcc-9.2.0 and glibc-2.30.

events.target_title: mutter-3.34 crashes with gnome on X11

note.body:
As further background, mutter-3.32 works fine on the same system, for both wayland and X11: that may (or may not) help to identify the cause of the issue with mutter-3.34.

As to your questions, I am using slackware64-current but somewhat modified so as to boot under systemd, and gnome-3.34 is compiled from source.  slackware64-current tends to be quite up-to-date so the issue may be new optimizations implemented in gcc-9.2 operating on undefined behavior in mutter.  It is also using an up-to-date version of xorg (xorg-server-1.20.5), but I doubt that is relevant.

Having said that, something in the build system of mutter-3.34 seems to have changed as compared with mutter-3.32, as I have noticed one other oddity.  If I build with --buildtype=debug then gnome-3.34 under X11 works fine but not under wayland (with wayland it hangs and times out).  The same happens if I build with --buildtype=plain and CFLAGS of '-O2 -fno-strict-aliasing'.  On the other hand with --buildtype=release then gnome-3.34 under wayland works fine but under X11 it crashes.  Weird.

I wonder if new compiler flags have been applied to mutter-3.34 (as compared to mutter-3.32) which is contributing to this.

events.target_title: mutter-3.34 crashes with gnome on X11

note.body:
Aha.  Further testing shows that if you include '-DG_DISABLE_CHECKS -DG_DISABLE_CAST_CHECKS' in CFLAGS, then mutter-3.34.1 crashes under X11 but not wayland.  If you don't include them X11 doesn't crash but wayland hangs.

Either mutter has uncovered a serious bug in gcc-9.2.0 and/or glibc-2.30; or gcc-9.2.0 has uncovered a bug in mutter-3.34 (probably arising from undefined behavior) which was not present in mutter-3.32.

events.target_title: mutter-3.34 crashes with gnome on X11

note.body:
I have now found the proximate cause of the problem, which appears to be a timing issue under X11 which results in `_clutter_stage_queue_event() being passed an invalid ClutterStage object on start-up.

The attached patch doesn't solve the underlying timing issue but it does operate as a work-around which allows X11 to start correctly even when mutter is built without the --buildtype=debug option.  With this patch gnome also starts OK under wayland (and it starts OK under wayland without the patch).

I cannot now reproduce the problem of gnome hanging on a wayland start-up where mutter is compiled with the --buildtype=debug option.  That seems to have been a problem with cached symbols with the frequent reinstallation of different library versions while I was trying to triage this.

Patch: [mutter-3.34.1.crash.patch](/uploads/312bc837637bfa1d813208e7cf7bd0bf/mutter-3.34.1.crash.patch)

events.target_title: mutter-3.34 crashes with gnome on X11

note.body: Thank you for letting me know.  When there is a known bug which will crash a tarball component of a "stable" gnome release (even one built with jhbuild), can some indication be made of that to prevent people having to spend their time dealing with it?

events.target_title: "Always show images" Doesn't Persist

note.body:
Yes, I can reliably reproduce the problem on every message. Since upgrading to 3.32.2, I can view an email, and I am then presented with Show Images / Always Show From Sender. If I click on Always Show From Sender, the images appear. I can then look at the next email message, but then pop back to the email I just clicked Always Show From Sender and the images are no longer visible and I am again prompted to show images or always show. It is exactly as in the video that the original reporter posted, and it is consistently happening with 3.32.2.

This appears to be a regression since I was using 0.12.4 previously and this appeared to be working just fine (and I assume this is how I have a semi-populated database of email addresses of images to display. Some of my more common email messages like those from my bug tracker display images consistently, but do not prompt me whether or not to display them -- it just works -- so I assume for these I clicked "always display" when using the earlier version of geary.)

Une dernière information.

Mes données sont sur un NAS. Les ressources sont montées en NFS. Le tout
est monté de la manière suivante (extrait de mon Wiki):

 1.
    Installation du protocole NFS <https://doc.ubuntu-fr.org/nfs>
 2.
    Modification /etc/fstab (192.168.0.41:/volume1/NosDocuments
    /home/media nfs users,atime,auto,rw,dev,exec,suid 0 0)
 3.
    Création répertoire de montage: mkdir /home/media & chown
    patrick,patrick /home/media
 4.
    Montage du disque de fstab: sudo mount -a
 5.
    Création liens logiques pour les répertoires /home
     1.
        cd && rm -r Documents Images Musique Vidéos
     2.
        ln -s /home/media/patrick/Documents /home/patrick/Documents
     3. .... idem pour les trois autres

Cordialement

events.target_title: Allow to disable the "App not responding" dialog feature
"“<application>” is not responding" dialog caused shell to become unresponsive

note.body:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/issues/1755

I also think that this dialog does way more harm than good. It's OK if the Gnome developers think that something like this could be helpful to some users, but it should at least be possible to disable this feature "somehow".

events.target_title: App not responding dialogs can be annoying

note.body:
There is a similar feature like this in Windows.

Some days ago I happened to have to use Windows and one application got unresponsive.

And it seems like the solution, that is used on Windows, is that the dialog telling that the application is unresponsive, is not displayed (or at least delayed pretty long) until you click into the unresponsive window.

Maybe this could be a solution to solve the problem discussed here. Don't automagically display this dialog until the user clicks into the window that is unresponsive.

events.target_title: Allow to disable the "App not responding" dialog feature

note.body:
While searching through the issues list, I found another issue where this dialog causes trouble:

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/issues/877

I don't see any reason why it should be impossible to disable this feature. I mean, it just can be one or two lines to check some hidden preference that can be set by someone who really knows that he doesn't want to see this dialog ever again.

But: If the extension, discussed here, finds its way to extensions.gnome.org, I think this would be an acceptable solution to solve this issue. Especially as this would be pretty easy to find for someone who wants to get rid of this dialog entirely.

events.target_title: Mutter fails to build in jhbuild: "error: field ‘media_type’ has incomplete type"
Mutter fails to build in jhbuild: "error: field ‘media_type’ has incomplete type"

note.body:
@LukeRobbins2112 I tried today again and I managed to build mutter.
All you need to do is to disable remote desktop in the build arguments (Unless remote desktop is important to you):
add this to ~/.config/jhbuildrc
```
module_mesonargs = {
        "mutter": "-Dremote_desktop=false"
}
```


I also changed the following line in mutter/src/backends/meta-profile.c (98:72) from
``` meta_dbus_sysprof3_profiler_complete_start (dbus_profiler, invocation, NULL); ```
to
``` meta_dbus_sysprof3_profiler_complete_start (dbus_profiler, invocation); ```

Good luck!

events.target_title: Horizontal Workspaces (Wayland) : cannot switch desktop with 4 fingers

note.body:
The bug is when you start the gesture with 4 fingers, and then you lift 1 (or more) fingers before the others, the gesture is cancelled no matter where you released your fingers. It's easier to lift all 4 fingers together when you rotate the hand 90 deg.

I managed to fix the bug, but when I started to create merge request, I noticed there is an open merge request that replaces the touchpad gesture handler entirely, So it was irrelevant.

I expect gnome 3.36 to fix the bug (although the merge request is open for about 5 months now, and it wasn't mereged yet

edit: now I see that 3 of 4 merge requests was merged, so it should be working now

events.target_title: Incorrect area layer order in image maps
Weird overnight crash possibly caused by a multi‑monitor setup
Cards NOT Moving
Using multiple keyboard shortcuts with sloppy focus affects unintended windows

note.body:
I recently switched back to Gnome3 after 6-7 years on Openbox and that's the only thing really annoying me.

The sloppy window selection mode does not only change the focus on window enter as it does in most other implementations so when I ALT+TAB to another visible window it will switch the focus right back to the previous window that still has the cursor over it.

I'd be happy to contribute a fix, if mutter maintainers agree that this is a bug, to me it is one since it obviously does not behave as the user wants it to, or a new switch such as "WindowEnter" that would only change the focus when the cursor changes window.

I found this documentation excerpt [`If the mouse is in a window, then it is focused;`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/master/doc/how-to-get-focus-right.txt#L21) this statement is true to the implementation but obviously not what the user wants when using a keyboard shortcut to change focus or move a window.

I note all the comments about how difficult it is to get an implementation that satisfies everyone but I think most people (at least everybody that I know who uses focus-follow-mouse at least) would rally to my opinion.

So I see a few ways to fix that :

1. Make the fix in the sloppy mode directly, which seems easiest (but I don't know the project, it seems to be very old code)
2. Create a new mode which implements focus-follow-mouse correctly
3. Create a plugin (maybe leverage the deprecated focus-follow-mouse plugin?)
4. Create a fork of mutter making the sloppy fix

events.target_title: Add .desktop file

note.body:
I'm using a distribution package (NixOS's), and your answer is kind of surprising to me: for most other packages I've come upon (disclaimer: I'm not the one packaging paperwork for NixOS), upstream already included the .desktop file, and the package just copied it over to the right location.

So I've looked at https://gitlab.gnome.org/World/OpenPaperwork/paperwork/blob/develop/paperwork-gtk/src/paperwork/frontend/shell.py#L103 ; and it looks like it is a static file. Would it make sense to have the .desktop be checked-in the (root of the) repository, and just copy it here, so as to make packagers' life a bit more easy in discovering it?
